Do something! Come and help us!
\q2 Rescue us because you love us as you promised to do.

\d A love song written by one of the descendants of Korah for the choir director, to be sung to the tune "Lilies."
\b
\q1

In my inner being I am aroused by something beautiful to write about,
\q2 a song that I will sing to the king.
\q2 The words of this song will be written by me, a skilled writer.
\b
\q1

O King, you are the most handsome man in the world,
\q2 and you always speak eloquently!
\q1 So we know that God has always blessed you.
\q1

You who are a mighty warrior, put on your sword!
\q2 You are glorious and majestic.
\q

Ride on like a great king 
\q2 to defend the truth that you speak
\q2 and the fair decisions that you make!
\q1 Because you fight in many battles,
\q2 you will learn to do deeds that your enemies will fear.
\q1

Your arrows are sharp,
\q2 and they pierce the hearts of your enemies.
\q2 Soldiers of many nations will fall at your feet.
\q1

The kingdom that God will give to you will remain forever.
\q2 You rule over people justly.
\q1

You love right actions,
\q2 and you hate evil actions.
\q1 Therefore God, your God, has chosen you to be king
\q2 and has caused you to be happier than any other king.
\q1

The perfume of various spices is on your robes.
\q2 Musicians entertain you in ivory palaces
\q2 by playing stringed instruments.
\q1

Among your wives are daughters of other kings.
\q2 At your right hand stands your bride, the queen, wearing beautiful ornaments of gold that comes from Ophir.
\b
\q1

Now I will say something to your bride:
\q1 "Listen to me carefully!
\q2 Forget the people who live in your home country,
\q2 forget your relatives!
\q1

Because you are very beautiful,
\q2 the king will desire to be with you.
\q2 He is your master, so you must obey him.
\q1

The people from the city of Tyre will bring gifts to you;
\q2 their rich people will try to persuade you to do favors for them.
\b
\q1

You, the king's bride, enter the palace
\q2 wearing beautiful robes made from gold thread."
\q1

O king, while she is wearing a gown that has many colors,
\q2 her woman servants will lead her to you.
\q2 She will have many other young women who accompany her.
\q1

They will be very joyful as they are led along
\q2 to enter your palace.
\b
\q1

Someday, your sons and your grandsons will become kings,
\q2 just as your ancestors were.
\q1 You will enable them to become rulers in many countries.
\q1

As for me, I will enable people in every generation to remember the great things that you have done,
\q2 and people will praise you forever.

\d A psalm written by one of the descendants of Korah for the choir director.
\b
\q1

So, even if the earth shakes,
\q2 we will not be afraid.
\q1 Even if the mountains fall into the middle of the sea,
\q1

and if the water in the sea roars and foams,
\q2 and if the hills shake violently,
\q2 we will not be afraid!
\b
\q1

Blessings that come from God are like a river that makes everyone in the city joyful, there where we worship him.
\q2 It is the city where the temple of God, who is greater than any other god, exists.
\q1

But Yahweh, commander of the angel armies, is with us;
\q2 the God whom Jacob worshiped is our refuge.
\b
\q1

Come and see the things that Yahweh does!
\q Come and see the things he has destroyed all over the earth.
\q

God says, "Be quiet and remember that I am God!
\q2 People of all nations will honor me.
\q2 People all over the earth will honor me."
\b
\q1

So never forget that Yahweh, commander of the angel armies, is with us;
\q2 the God whom Jacob worshiped is our refuge.

\d A psalm written by one of the descendants of Korah for the choir director
\b
\q1

You people all over the world, clap your hands!
\q2 Shout joyfully to praise God!
\q1

He chose for us this land where we now live;
\q2 we Israelite people, whom he loves, are proud that we own this land.
\b
\q1

God has gone up into his temple.
\q2 The people shouted joyfully and blew trumpets as he went up.
\q1

Sing songs to praise our God!
\q2 Sing to praise him !
\q2 Sing to God, our king!
\b
\q1

God sits on his sacred throne
\q2 as he rules over the people of all ethnic groups.
\q1

\d A psalm written by one of the descendants of Korah
\b
\q1

Yahweh is great, and he deserves to be greatly praised in the city where he lives,
\q2 which is built on Zion, his sacred hill.
\q1

That city on a high hill is beautiful;
\q2 it is the city where the true God, the great king, lives,
\q2 and it causes people all over the world to rejoice when they see it.
\q1

God is in the strong towers there,
\q2 and he shows that he protects the people in that city.
\b
\q1

Many kings gathered with their armies to attack our city,
\q1

Because they were very afraid, they trembled
\q2 like a woman who is about to give birth to a child.
\q1

They shook as ships sailing from Tarshish shake in a strong wind.
\b
\q1

We had heard that this city was glorious,
\q1 and now we have seen that it is.
\q2 It is the city in which Yahweh, commander of the angel armies, lives.
\q2 It is the city that God will preserve forever.
\b
\q1

God, here in your temple we think about how you love us as you promised to do.
\q1

People all over the earth will praise you
\q2 because you rule powerfully and justly.
\q1

The people who live at Mount Zion should be happy!
\q1 The people in all the cities of Judah should rejoice
\q2 because you judge people fairly.
\b
\q1

notice the walls there and examine their strongest parts
\q2 so that you can tell your children about them.
\q1

Say to your children, "This is the city of our God, the one who lives forever;
\q2 he will guide us during all of our lives."

\d A psalm written by one of the descendants of Korah for the choir director.
\b
\q1

You people of all people groups, listen!
\q1 You people all over the world,
\q2

important people and unimportant people,
\q2 rich people and poor people,
\q1 everyone, listen to what I am saying.
\q1

For what I am thinking is very sensible,
\q2 and what I say will enable you to become wise.
\q1

I think about wise words to tell you,
\q2 and while I play my harp, I explain what they mean.
\b
\q1

I do not worry when I am in trouble,
\q2 when I am surrounded by my enemies.
\q1

These are evil men who trust that things will always go well for them because they are wealthy
\q2 and who boast about being very rich.
\q1

They may be rich, but no one can pay God money
\q2 so that he can live forever!
\q1 No one can pay God enough so that God will allow him to continue to live
\q1

because that cost is too big,
\q2 and he will never be able to pay enough
\q1

so that he will live forever
\q2 and never die and be buried!
\b
\q1

We see that foolish and stupid people die,
\q1 but we see that wise people also die;
\q2 they all leave their wealth, and others inherit it.
\q1

They once had houses on land that they owned,
\q1 but now their graves are their homes forever,
\q2 the place where they will stay for all time!
\b
\q1

Even if people are great, that cannot prevent them from dying;
\q2 people all die, the same as the animals do.
\b
\q1

That is what happens to those who foolishly trust in what they have accomplished,
\q2 to those who are delighted in all that they possess.
\q1

They are certain to die just like sheep
\q2 when a shepherd leads them away to be slaughtered. 
\q1 In the morning the righteous people will rule over them,
\q1 and then those wealthy people will die and their bodies will quickly decay in their graves;
\q2 they will be where dead people are, far from their homes.
\q1

But it is certain that God will rescue me so that I am not held fast in the place of the dead;
\q2 he will take me to himself.
\b
\q1

While a rich person is alive, he congratulates himself,
\q2 and people praise him for being successful,
\q1

but he will die and join his ancestors,
\q2 who will never see daylight again.
\b
\q1

Even if someone is great, that cannot prevent him from dying;
\q2 he will die, the same as the animals do.

God, the all-powerful one, speaks;
\q1 he summons all people,
\q2 from the east to the west.
\q1

His glory shines from Mount Zion in Jerusalem,
\q2 an extremely beautiful city.
\q

Our God comes to us,
\q2 and he is not silent.
\q1 A great fire is in front of him,
\q2 and a storm is around him.
\q1

He comes to judge his people.
\q1 He shouts to the angels in heaven
\q2 and to the people on the earth.
\q1

He says, "Summon those who faithfully worship me,
\q2 those who made a covenant with me by offering sacrifices to me."
\q

The angels in heaven declare,
\q2 "God is righteous,
\q2 and he is the supreme judge."
\b
\q1

God says, "My people, listen!
\q2 You Israelite people, listen,
\q1 as I, your God, say what you have done that is wrong.
\q1

I am not rebuking you for making sacrifices to me,
\q2 for the offerings that you always burn on the altar for me.
\q1

But I do not really need the bulls from your barns
\q2 and the goats from your pens that you sacrifice,
\q1

because all the animals in the forest belong to me,
\q2 and all the cattle on a thousand hills also belong to me.
\q1

I know and own all the birds in the mountains, 
\q2 and all the creatures that move around in the fields.
\q1

So if I were hungry, I would not tell you to bring me some food
\q2 because everything in the world belongs to me!
\q1

I do not eat the flesh of the bulls that you sacrifice,
\q2 and I do not drink the blood of the goats that you offer to me.
\q1

The sacrifice that I really want is that you thank me
\q2 and do all that you have promised to do.
\q1

Pray to me when you have troubles.
\q2 If you do that, I will rescue you, and then you will praise me.
\q1

But I say this to the wicked people:
\q1 Why do you recite my commandments
\q2 or talk about the covenant that I made with you?
\q1

For you have refused to allow me to discipline you,
\q2 and you have rejected what I told you to do.
\q1

Every time that you see a thief, you become his friend,
\q2 and you spend much time with those who commit adultery.
\q1

You are always talking about doing wicked things,
\q2 and you are always trying to deceive people.
\q1

You are always accusing members of your own family
\q2 and slandering them.
\q1

You did all those things, and I did not say anything to you,
\q2 so you thought that I was a sinner just like you.
\q1 But now I rebuke you and accuse you, right in front of you.
\b
\q1

So, all you who have ignored me, pay attention to this,
\q1 because if you do not, I will tear you to pieces,
\q2 and there will be no one to rescue you.
\q

The sacrifice that truly honors me is to thank me for what I have done;
\q2 and I will save those who always do the things that I want them to."

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director, concerning the time when the prophet Nathan rebuked David after he had committed adultery with Bathsheba.
\b
\q1

O God, act mercifully toward me
\q2 because you love me faithfully;
\q2 because you are very merciful,
\q2 forget the ways that I disobeyed you!
\q1

Make me acceptable to you again, even though I did wrong things;
\q2 forgive the guilt of my sin and accept me.
\b
\q1

You, you only, are the one I that have really sinned against,
\q2 and you have seen the evil things that I have done.
\q1 When you say that I am guilty, you are right,
\q2 and when you judge me, you justly say that I deserve to be punished.
\q1

What you desire is that in my inner being I desire what is true
\q2 in order that you can teach me in my inner being how to act wisely.
\b
\q1

Allow me to rejoice again;
\q2 you have made me immeasurably sad,
\q1 but now let me rejoice again.
\q1

Do not continue to remember the sins that I have committed;
\q2 forget the evil things that I have done.
\b
\q1

O God, make me want to do the things that you approve of.
\q2 Make me want to do only what is right.
\q1

Do not reject me as one of your people,
\q2 and do not make your holy Spirit leave me.
\q1

Make me happy again by rescuing me from my guilt,
\q2 and always help me by making me sincerely want to obey you.
\b
\q1

O God, you are the one who saves me;
\q2 forgive me for being guilty of causing someone who was not my enemy to die.
\q2 When you do that, I will sing joyfully about your being very good and righteous.
\q1

O Yahweh, help me to speak
\q2 in order that I may praise you.
\q1

When people only bring sacrifices to you, that does not please you.
\q2 If that were enough to please you, I would do the same.
\q1 But you are not pleased with burnt offerings alone.
\q1

The sacrifice that you really want is for people to be truly humble and sorry for having sinned.
\q2 O God, you will not refuse that kind of sacrifice.
\b
\q1

When that happens, they will bring you the proper sacrifices:
\q2 normal animal sacrifices and sacrifices to be completely burned.
\q2 They will burn young bulls on your altar,
\q2 and you will be pleased.

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director when Doeg went to Saul and said, "David has gone to talk with Ahimelech, the high priest."
\b
\q1

You proud man, you think that you are strong;
\q2 you boast about the trouble that you make for others, 
\q1 but God faithfully protects people from you every day.
\q1

All during the day you plan to get rid of others;
\q1 what you say is like a sharp blade,
\q2 and you are always deceiving others.
\q1

You like doing what is evil more than you like doing what is good,
\q2 and you like telling lies more than you like telling the truth.
\q1

You, the one who says things to deceive people,
\q2 you like to say things that hurt people!
\b
\q1

But God will get rid of you forever;
\q2 he will grab you and drag you from your home
\q2 and take you away from this world where people are alive.
\q1

When righteous people see that, they will be awestruck,
\q2 and they will laugh at what happened to you, and say,
\q1

But I am secure because I worship in God's temple;
\q2 I am like a strong green olive tree.
\q1 I trust in God, who faithfully loves us forever.
\b
\q

God, I will always thank you for everything you have done.
\q2 I will wait patiently because you are so good, 
\q2 especially when I stand before your faithful people.

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director, to be sung using a tune called "Mahalath."
\b
\q1

Only foolish people say to themselves, "There is no God!"
\q1 People who say that are corrupt; they commit terrible sins;
\q2 there is not one of them who does what is good.
\b
\q1

God looks down from heaven and sees humans;
\q1 he looks to see if any man is very wise
\q2 and seeks to know God.
\q1

But everyone has turned away from God. They are depraved and do disgusting, filthy things.
\q2 No one does what is good.
\b
\q1

Will all these evil people never learn what God will do to them?
\q1 They hurt Yahweh's people with terrible violence. They had no guilt in what they did. They had the same expression on their faces as people eating bread at dinner.
\q2 And what is worse is that they never prayed to Yahweh.
\q1

But someday those people will become very terrified,
\q2 although they have nothing to fear.
\q1 For God will cause those who attack you to die,
\q2 and he will scatter their bones.
\q1 They have rejected God,
\q2 so he will cause them to be defeated and completely disgraced.
\b
\q1

I wish that God would come and rescue the Israelite people!
\q2 God, when you bless your people again,
\q1 all the Israelite people, all the descendants of Jacob, will rejoice.

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director, to be accompanied by stringed instruments; it was written when the people of Ziph went to Saul and told him that David was hiding in their area.
\b
\q1

God, by your power save me from my enemies,
\q2 and show people that I have not done anything that is wrong!
\q1

because strangers are trying to attack me;
\q2 proud men are wanting to kill me,
\q2 men who have no respect for you.
\b
\q1

He will cause the evil things that they want to do to me to happen to them instead;
\q2 because you faithfully do what you have promised to me, destroy them.
\b
\q1

you have rescued me from all my troubles,
\q2 and I have seen that you have defeated my enemies.

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director, to be accompanied by stringed instruments
\b
\q1

God, listen to my prayer,
\q2 and do not turn away from me while I am pleading with you.
\q1

Listen to me and answer me
\q2 because I am overwhelmed by all my troubles.
\q1

I am terrified,
\q2 and I am very much afraid that I will die.
\q1

I said, "I wish that I had wings like a dove!
\q1 If I had wings, I would fly away and find a place to rest.
\q1

I would fly far away
\q2 and live in the wilderness.
\q

I would quickly find a safe place
\q2 where my enemies could not strike me like a strong wind and rainstorm."
\b
\q1

Lord, confuse my enemies and cause their plans to fail.
\q2 I saw them hurting others by their violence and causing riots throughout the city.
\q1

During each day and night they march around on top of its walls,
\q2 committing crimes and causing trouble.
\q

They destroy things everywhere.
\q2 They oppress people and defraud people in the marketplaces.
\b
\q1

If it were an enemy who was making fun of me,
\q2 I could endure it.
\q1 If it were someone who hates me, who despises me,
\q2 I could hide from him.
\q1

But it is someone who is just like me, my companion,
\q2 someone who was my friend who is doing this to me.
\q1

We previously had many good talks together;
\q2 we walked around together in God's temple.
\b
\q1

I desire that my enemies will go down alive
\q2 to the place where the dead people are.
\q2 I want this because they do evil things in their homes.
\b
\q1

But I will ask Yahweh, my God, to help me,
\q2 and he will save me.
\q1

Each morning, noontime, and evening I tell him what I am concerned about, and I moan,
\q2 and he hears my voice.
\q1

He saves my life and makes me safe
\q1 when I am fighting a terrible battle against my enemies.
\q2 There are many enemies coming to fight against me!
\q1

God is the one who has ruled everything forever,
\q2 and he will put those who fought against me in their place.
\q1 He will cause my enemies to be defeated and disgraced
\q2 because they do not change their evil behavior
\q2 and because they do not have any respect for God.
\b
\q1

My companion, whom I mentioned previously, betrayed his friends
\q2 and broke the agreement that he made with them.
\q1

What he said was as easy to listen to as butter is easy to swallow,
\q2 but in his inner being he hated people;
\q1 his words were as soothing as olive oil,
\q2 but they hurt people as sharp swords do.
\b
\q1

Put your troubles in Yahweh's hands,
\q2 and he will take care of you;
\q1 he will never allow disaster to destroy righteous people.
\q1

God, you will cause murderers and liars to die before they have lived half as long as they expect to live;
\q2 but as for me, I will trust in you.

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director, concerning the time the Philistines seized David in Gath; to be sung using the tune "Dove on distant oaks."
\b
\q1

God, act mercifully toward me because men are attacking me!
\q2 All day long an enemy presses closer and closer to me because they want to take my life.
\q1

All day long my enemies seek to crush the life from me,
\q2 there are many enemies attacking me!
\b
\q1

But whenever I am afraid,
\q2 I trust in you.
\q1

God, I praise you because you do what you have promised;
\q2 I trust in you, and then I am not afraid.
\q2 Ordinary humans certainly cannot harm me!
\b
\q1

In order to cause trouble for me, they hide
\q2 and watch everything that I do,
\q2 waiting for an opportunity to kill me.
\b
\q1

You have counted all the times that I have been wandering alone;
\q2 it is as though you have put all my tears in a bottle
\q2 so that you can see how much I have cried.
\q2 You have counted my tears and written the number in your book.
\b
\q1

I trust in you, and as a result, I will not be afraid.
\q2 I know that humans cannot really harm me!
\b
\q1

because you have rescued me from being killed;
\q2 you have kept me from stumbling.
\q2 And so I will continue to live with God every day
\q in his light that gives me life.

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director, when David went into a cave to escape from Saul; to be sung using the tune "Do not destroy."
\b
\q1

God, act mercifully toward me!
\q1 Act mercifully toward me because I am coming to you to protect me.
\q2 I request you to protect me as little birds are protected under their mother's wings
\q2 until the storm is ended.
\b
\q1

God, you who are greater than all other gods,
\q2 I cry out to you, the one who enables me to be all that you desire.
\q1

You will answer me from heaven and rescue me,
\q2 but you will cause those who oppress me to be defeated and disgraced!
\q2 God will always faithfully love me as he has promised me.
\b
\q1

God, show in the heavens that you are very great!
\q2 Show your glory to people all over the earth!
\b
\q1

It is as if my enemies have spread a net to seize me,
\q2 and I became very distressed.
\q1 It is as if they have dug a deep pit along the path where I walk,
\q2 but they themselves fell into it!
\b
\q1

God, I am very confident in you.
\q1 I will sing to you,
\q2 and I will praise you while I sing.
\q1

It is an honor to wake up and praise you.
\q2 I will arise before the sun rises
\q2 and praise you while I play my big harp or my lyre.
\b
\q1

For your love for us is as great as the distance from the earth to the sky,
\q2 and your faithfulness to us goes up to  the clouds.
\q1

God, show in the heavens that you are very great!
\q2 Show your glory to people all over the earth!

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director, to be sung using the tune "Do not destroy."
\b
\q1

No, in your inner beings you think only about doing what is wrong,
\q2 and you commit violent crimes everywhere in this land of Israel.
\q1

Wicked people do wrong things and tell lies from the time that they are born.
\q1

What wicked people say injures people like the venom of a snake.
\q2 They refuse to listen to commands; it is as though they were deaf cobras.
\q

As a result, like a snake that does not respond when a charmer plays a flute or when someone sings magic songs,
\q2 they do not pay attention when others rebuke them.
\b
\q1

God, as for these enemies who want to attack me like young lions,
\q2 break the teeth in their mouths!
\q1

Cause them to disappear as water disappears in dry ground!
\q2 Cause the arrows that they shoot to have no heads!
\q1

Cause them to become like snails that disappear in the slime;
\q2 cause them to be like a baby that is born dead!
\b
\q1

I hope that you will get rid of them
\q2 as fast as thornbushes are blown away after they are cut.
\q1

Then people will say, "It is true that there is a reward for righteous people;
\q2 and there is indeed a God who judges people justly here on the earth!"

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director, when Saul, wanting to kill David, sent men to watch David's house.
\b
\q1

Keep me safe from men who want to do what is wicked,
\q2 from men who are murderers!
\b
\q1

Look! They are waiting to kill me!
\q2 Fierce men have gathered to assault me.
\q1 Yahweh, they are doing that even though I have not done what is wrong!
\q1

It is not because I have committed any sin against them
\q2 that they run and get ready to attack me. Please look at my situation and help me.
\q1

Yahweh my God, commander of the angel armies, the one we Israelites worship,
\q2 arise and punish the people of all the nations who do not honor you;
\q2 do not act mercifully toward those wicked people who have acted treacherously toward us.
\b
\q1

They return each evening,
\q2 snarling like vicious dogs as they prowl around this city.
\q

They loudly say terrible things;
\q2 they say things that destroy as much as swords do,
\q1 because they are saying, "No one will hear us!"
\q1

But Yahweh, you laugh at them.
\q2 You scoff at the people of the pagan nations.
\b
\q1

Because you love me, you will come to save me as you have promised;
\q2 you will allow me to watch while you defeat my enemies.
\b
\q1

But do not kill them immediately;
\q2 it is good that my people should not forget how you punished them!
\q1 Instead, Lord, you who are like a shield that protects us,
\q2 scatter them by your power, and then defeat them.
\q1

Because what they say is sinful,
\q2 allow them to be trapped for being proud.
\q1 Because they are always cursing and telling lies,
\q1

because you are angry, get rid of them;
\q2 destroy them completely
\q2 so that people will know that you rule over us, your Israelite people,
\q2 and that you rule over all the earth.
\b
\q1

They return each evening,
\q2 snarling like vicious dogs as they prowl around this city.
\q1

They roam around, searching for food
\q1 and if they do not find enough, they growl like dogs.
\q1

But as for me, I will sing about your power;
\q2 every morning I will sing joyfully about your faithfully loving us.
\q1 I will sing about how you protected me when I was very distressed.
\b
\q1

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director, a psalm for teaching, to be sung using the tune "Lily of the promise." David wrote it during the wars in northern Syria, and when Joab's army, after returning from the battle, killed twelve thousand of the Edom people group in Salt Valley.
\b
\q1

I prayed, "God, you have rejected us Israelites!
\q1 Because you have been angry with us,
\q2 you have enabled our enemies to break through our ranks.
\q1 Please enable us to be strong again!
\q1

It was as though you made a big earthquake in which the ground split open.
\q1 So now, make us strong again,
\q2 because it is as though our country is falling apart.
\q1

You have caused us, your people, to suffer very much;
\q2 it is as though you had taken away our strength by making us drink strong wine.
\b
\q1

But you have raised a battle flag for those who honor you.
\q2 They will show your banner when they face the enemies' arrows.
\q1

Answer our prayers and enable us by your power to defeat our enemies
\q2 so that we, the people you love, will be saved."
\b
\q1

Then God answered my prayer and spoke from his temple, saying,
\q1 "Because I have conquered your enemies, I will divide the city of Shechem,
\q2 and I will distribute among my people the land in Succoth Valley.
\q1

Because I want to defeat the people of Edom,
\q1 who will lead my army to their capital city that has strong walls around it?"
\q1

We need you to help us when we fight against our enemies
\q2 because the help that humans can give us is worthless.
\q

But with you helping us, we will win;
\q2 you will enable us to defeat our enemies.

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director, to be accompanied by musical instruments.
\b
\q1

God, listen to me
\q2 and answer my prayer.
\q1

While I am discouraged and far from my home,
\q1 I am calling out to you.
\b
\q1 Lead me to a place that will be like a high rock 
\q2 on top of which I will be safe.
\q1

You have been my refuge;
\q2 you have been like a strong tower 
\q2 in which my enemies cannot attack me.
\b
\q1

Allow me to live close to your sacred tent all during my life!
\q1 Allow me to be safe as a little bird is safe under its mother's wings.
\q1

God, you heard me when I solemnly promised to give offerings to you;
\q2 you have given to me the blessings that belong to those who have an awesome respect for you.
\b
\q1

I am the king of Israel;
\q1 please allow me to live and rule for many years,
\q2 and allow my descendants to rule also.
\q1

Allow us to rule forever while you observe us;
\q2 watch over us while you faithfully love us and do for us what you promised.
\b
\q1

If you do that, I will always sing to praise you 
\q2 while I offer to you each day the sacrifices that I promised to give to you.

\d A psalm written by David for Jeduthun, the choir leader
\b
\q1

God is the only one who can give me peace in my inner being,
\q2 and he is the one who saves me from my enemies.
\q1

Only he is like a huge rock on which I can be safe;
\q2 he is like a fortress high up that my enemies cannot climb.
\b
\q1

When will you, my enemies, stop attacking me?
\q2 I feel that I am as weak against you as a leaning wall or a broken-down fence.
\q1

My enemies plan to remove me from my important position so that people no longer honor me.
\q2 They delight in telling lies.
\q1 They bless people by what they say,
\q2 but in their inner beings they curse those people.
\b
\q1

God is the one who saves me and honors me.
\q2 He is like a huge,
 strong rock on which I can find shelter.
\q1

You my people, always trust in him.
\q2 Tell him all your troubles
\q2 because we go to him for safety.
\b
\q1

People who are considered to be unimportant are as unreliable as a breath of air;
\q2 people who are considered to be important also really amount to nothing.
\q1 If you put them all on a scale, it would be as if they weighed less than a puff of air.
\q1

Do not trust in money gained by extorting it from others;
\q2 do not try to gain anything by robbing others.
\q1 If you become very wealthy, do not trust in your money.
\b
\q1

I have heard God say more than once that he is the one who really has power,
\q1

and that he is the one who faithfully loves us, as he promised.
\q2 He rewards every one of us according to the deeds that we do.

\d A psalm written by David when he was in the wilderness in Judah.
\b
\q1

God, you are the God whom I worship.
\q1 I greatly desire to be with you
\q2 as a person in a dry hot wilderness greatly desires some water.
\b
\q1

I have been with you in your temple
\q1 In order to see that you are loving and powerful.
\q1

You always love me, as you promised in your covenant; this is worth more than my entire life,
\q2 so I will always praise you.
\q1

You fill me up and you meet every need I have. 
\q2 My response to you is much like when I eat a delicious banquet of rich foods 
\q2 and the food fills me.
\q2 I will have great happiness when I praise you with the words that I speak about you.
\b
\q1

While I lie on my bed, I think about you.
\q1 I think about you all during the night.
\q1

For you have always helped me,
\q2 and I sing joyfully knowing that you protect me
\q2 as a bird protects her young under her wings.
\q1

they will be killed in battles 
\q2 and their corpses will be eaten by dogs.
\b
\q1

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director.
\b
\q1

God, listen to me as I tell you the things about which I am worried.
\q2 I am afraid of my enemies; please save me from them.
\q1

Protect me from what wicked men are planning to do to me;
\q2 protect me from that group of men who do what is evil.
\b
\q1

They are not afraid of anyone; they lie about people and slander those who have done no wrong.
\q2 They are like someone who suddenly jumps up from where he is hiding and shoots arrows at his enemies.
\b
\q1

They encourage each other about doing the evil things that they are planning to do;
\q2 they talk with each other about where they can set traps to catch people.
\q2 They say, "No one will see what we are doing
\q1

because we have planned very well the things that we are going to do."
\q2 What people can think and plan in their inner beings is truly amazing!
\b
\q1

But it will be as though God will shoot his arrows at them,
\q2 and suddenly they will be wounded.
\q1

Because what they say proves they are guilty, God will get rid of them.
\q2 Everyone who sees what has happened to them will shake their heads to mock them.
\b
\q1

Then everyone will be afraid to sin because of what might happen to them also;
\q2 they will tell others what God has done,
\q2 and they themselves will think much about it.
\q1

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director.
\b
\q1

God, it is right for us to praise you in Jerusalem
\q1 and to do what we have promised you that we would do
\q2

because you answer our prayers.
\q1 People everywhere will come to you
\q2

Our many sins are like a very heavy burden to us,
\q1 but you forgive us.
\q1

How fortunate are those whom you have chosen
\q2 to always be in your temple courtyards.
\q1 We will be satisfied with all the blessings that you will give us because we worship you in your sacred temple.
\b
\q1

You are the one who put the mountains in their places,
\q2 showing that you are very powerful.
\q1

You are the one who calms the seas when they roar,
\q2 and stop the waves from pounding on the shore;
\q1 you also calm people when they cause a lot of trouble.
\q1

People who live in very remote places on the earth
\q2 are awed by the miracles that you perform;
\q1 because of what you do,
\q2 people who live far to the west and far to the east shout joyfully.
\b
\q1

You take care of the soil and send rain,
\q2 causing many good things to grow;
\q1 you fill the streams with water
\q2 and cause grain to grow.
\q1 This is what you have determined would happen.
\q1

You send plenty of rain on the fields that have been plowed,
\q2 and you fill the furrows with water.
\q1 With showers you soften the hard clods of soil,
\q2 and you bless the soil by causing young plants to grow.
\q1

The pastures in the wilderness are wet with the morning dew, 
\q2 it is as though the hills are singing joyful songs. 
\q1

\d A psalm that is a song for the choir director.
\b
\q1

Tell everyone on the earth
\q2 that they should sing joyfully to praise God!
\q1

They should sing songs that say that God is very great,
\q2 and they should tell everyone that he is very glorious!
\q1

They should say to God, "The things that you do are awesome!
\q2 Your power is very great,
\q2 with the result that your enemies cringe in front of you."
\q1

Everyone on the earth will worship God,
\q2 sing to praise him,
\q2 and honor him.
\b
\q1

Come and think about what God has done!
\q1 Think about the awesome things that he has done among people.
\q1

He caused the sea to become dry land,
\q2 with the result that our ancestors were able to walk right through it.
\q1 There we rejoiced because of what he had done.
\q1

He rules forever by his power,
\q2 and he keeps watching all the nations to see what evil things they do.
\q2 The nations that want to rebel against him should not be proud.
\b
\q1

You people of all nations, praise our God!
\q2 Praise him loudly in order that people will hear you as you praise him.
\q1

He has kept us alive,
\q2 and he has not allowed us to fall into disaster.
\b
\q1

God, you have tested us;
\q1 you have allowed us to experience great difficulties to make our lives become pure
\q2 as people put precious metals in a hot fire to burn out what is impure.
\q1

It is as if you allowed us to fall into traps,
\q2 and you forced us to endure difficult things that were like heavy loads to carry on our backs.
\q1

You allowed our enemies to trample on us;
\q2 we experienced difficulties walking through fires and floods,
\q1 but now you have made us safe.
\b
\q1

I will bring sheep to be burned on the altar,
\q2 and I will also sacrifice bulls and goats;
\q2 when they are burning, you will be pleased as the smoke rises up to you.
\b
\q1

All you people who have a reverential respect for God, come and listen,
\q2 and I will tell you what he has done for me.
\q1

I called out to him to help me,
\q2 and I praised him while I was speaking to him.
\q1

If I had ignored the sins that I had committed,
\q2 the Lord would not have paid any attention to me.
\q1

But because I confessed my sins, God has listened to me
\q2 and has paid attention to my prayers.
\q

\d A psalm for the choir director, to be accompanied by stringed instruments.
\b
\q1

Do this in order that everyone in the world may know what you want them to do,
\q2 and the people of all nations may know that you have the power to save them.
\b
\q1

I desire that the people of all nations will be glad and sing joyfully
\q2 because you judge the people groups equally,
\q2 and you guide all the nations in the world.
\q1

God, I desire that the people groups may praise you;
\q1 I want them all to praise you!
\b
\q1

Because God has blessed us,
\q1 I desire that all people everywhere on the earth may have an awesome respect for him.

God, arise and scatter your enemies,
\q1 and cause those who hate you to run away from you.
\q1

As wind blows smoke away,
\q2 you chase your enemies away.
\q1 As wax melts when it is near a fire,
\q2 may you cause wicked people to disappear.
\q1

God, who lives in his sacred temple, is like a father to those who are orphans,
\q2 and he is the one who protects widows.
\q1

He provides families for those who have no one to live with.
\q1 He frees prisoners and enables them to be successful,
\q2 but those who rebel against him will be forced to live in a very hot and dry land.
\b
\q1

God, you led your people out of Egypt,
\q2 and then you marched with them through the desert.
\q1

After you did that,
\q1 the earth shook at Mount Sinai when you appeared to your people,
\q2 and rain poured down from the sky, and your people worshiped you.
\q1

You caused plenty of rain to fall there in the wilderness,
\q2 and so you enabled good crops to grow again on that land that you gave to us Israelites.
\q1

Your people built homes there;
\q2 because you were good to them, you provided food for those who were poor.
\b
\q1

The Lord spoke this message,
\q2 and many people took his message to other places.
\q1

12-13 They proclaimed, "Many kings and their armies are running away from our army!"
\q2 When our army brought back to their homes the things that they captured,
\q1 the women who were at home divided up those things among themselves and among their families.
\q2 They got statues of pigeons whose wings were covered with silver
\q2 and whose feathers were covered with pure yellow gold.
But some of the people stayed with the sheep and did not go to fight in the battle. Why did you not go?
\q1

When Almighty God scattered the enemy kings and their armies,
\q2 it reminded me of a snowstorm on Mount Zalmon!
\b
\q1

There is a very high mountain in the Bashan hills,
\q1 a mountain that has many peaks.
\q1

But the people who live near that mountain should not envy those who live near Mount Zion,
\q2 the mountain on which God chose to live!
\q1 Yahweh will live there forever!
\q1

After we defeated all our enemies,
\q1 it was as though the Lord, surrounded by many thousands of strong chariots, descended from Mount Sinai
\q1 and came into the sacred temple in Jerusalem.
\q1

He ascended the sacred mountain where his temple is
\q1 and took with him many people who had been captured in battles;
\q2 he received gifts from the enemies whom he had defeated.
\q1 He received gifts even from those who had rebelled against him,
\q2 and Yahweh, our God, will live there in his sacred temple forever.
\b
\q1

Our God is the God who saves us;
\q2 He is Yahweh, our Lord, the one who allows us to escape from dying in battles.
\b
\q1

But God will smash the heads of his enemies,
\q2 the long-haired skulls of those who continue to behave sinfully.
\q1

The Lord said, "I will bring back the corpses of my enemies who were killed in Bashan,
\q1 and I will bring back those who sank deep in the ocean and drowned.
\q2

I will do that so that you may wash your feet in their blood,
\q2 and your dogs can also lap up some of your enemies' blood."
\b
\q1

God, many people see you march triumphantly into your sacred temple,
\q2 celebrating that you have defeated your enemies.
\q2 You march like a king does, and a large crowd walks with you.
\q1

The singers are in front, and the people who play stringed instruments are at the rear,
\q2 and young women who are beating their tambourines are between them.
\q1

First come the people of the tribe of Benjamin, the smallest tribe,
\q2 and following them come the leaders of the tribe of Judah and their group,
\q1 and following them come the leaders of the tribes of Zebulun and Naphtali.
\q1

You people of Israel, God made our tribes very strong.
\q2 God, help us with your power as you helped us in the past.
\q1

Shout as you defeat your enemies, such as those in Egypt, who are like wild animals living in the reeds.
\q1 Shout as you defeat the powerful nations, who are like herds of bulls.
\q1 Shame them; make them bow down and give you gifts.
\q2 Drive away and scatter the people groups who love to attack other nations.
\q1

Then the leaders of Egypt will bring gifts to you.
\q2 then the people in Ethiopia will rush to lift up their hands to praise you.
\b
\q1

You people who are citizens of kingdoms all over the world, sing to God!
\q1 Sing praises to Yahweh!
\q1

Sing to the God, the one who rides in the sky,
\q2 the sky that he created long ago.
\q1 Listen as he shouts with a very powerful voice.
\q1

Proclaim that God is very powerful;
\q2 he is the king that rules over Israel,
\q2 and in the skies he also shows that he is powerful.
\q1

God is awesome as he comes out of his sacred temple;
\q2 he is the God whom we Israelite people worship.
\q1 He gives power and strength to his people.
\b
\q1 Praise God!

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director.
\b
\q1

O God, save me
\q2 because I am in great danger.
\q2 It is as though the flood water were up to my neck, and I were about to drown.
\q1

I continue to sink in the deep mud,
\q2 and there is no solid ground for me to stand on.
\q1 I am in deep water,
\q2 and the flood is swirling around me.
\q1

I am exhausted from calling out for help;
\q2 my throat is very dry.
\q1 Because I have cried so much as I have waited for God to help me,
\q2 my eyes are swollen from tears.
\q1

Those who hate me when there is no reason to hate me
\q2 are more than the number of hairs on my head!
\q1 Those who want to get rid of me are strong,
\q2 and they tell lies about me.
\q1 They demand that I return to them things that I did not steal!
\q1

O God, you see the sins that I have committed.
\q2 You know that I have foolishly disobeyed your laws.
\b
\q1

O Yahweh God, commander of the angel armies,
\q2 do not allow the wrong things that I have done
\q2 cause those who trust in you to be disappointed.
\q1 O God, whom we Israelite people worship,
\q2 do not allow me to cause them to be shamed.
\q1

People have insulted me because I am devoted to you.
\q2 They have thoroughly humiliated me.
\q1

Some people have despised your temple;
\q2 but because I have tried to keep your temple holy, people have caused trouble for me.
\q1 So it is as though those who are insulting you are also insulting me.
\q1

When I have humbled myself and fasted
\q2 to show my sadness about the disgraceful things that they have done to your temple,
\q2 they just insult me.
\q1

When I put on rough sackcloth to show that I am sad,
\q2 they laugh at me.
\q1

Even the elders of the city say bad things about me.
\q2 The drunkards of the city sing disgusting songs about me.
\b
\q1

But Yahweh, I will continue praying to you.
\q1 At the time that you choose, answer me and rescue me
\q2 because you faithfully love me, as you have promised to do.
\q1

Do not allow me to sink anymore in the mud.
\q1 Rescue me from those who hate me!
\q2 Lift me up out of these deep waters!
\q1

O Yahweh, answer my prayer and help me
\q2 because you are good 
\q2 and I can depend on your love for me.
\q2 You have not punished me for what I deserve. 
\q1 I know you will listen to me!
\q1

Do not hide yourself from me;
\q1 answer me quickly
\q2 because I am in great trouble.
\q1

You know that I am insulted
\q2 and that people shame and dishonor me;
\q1 you know who all my enemies are.
\q1

Their insults have deeply offended me,
\q2 and I feel helpless.
\q1 I searched for someone who would pity me,
\q2 but there was no one.
\q1 I wanted someone to encourage me,
\q2 but there was no one.
\q1

Instead, they gave me food that tasted like poison,
\q2 and when I was thirsty, they gave me sour wine to drink.
\b
\q1

I hope that their eyes become dim so that they cannot see anything
\q2 and that their backs will become weaker and weaker.
\q1

Show them that you are very angry with them!
\q2 Because of your great anger, chase them and catch them.
\q1

Do this because they persecute those whom you have punished,
\q2 they look at how those whom you have punished suffer, and they tell others about it.
\q1

Keep making a record of all their sins,
\q2 do not fail to punish them for the evil things that they have done.
\q1

Erase their names from the book containing the names of those who have eternal life;
\q2 do not include them in the list of righteous people.
\b
\q1

As for me, I have pain and am suffering.
\q2 O God, protect me and rescue me.
\b
\q1

When God does that, I will sing as I praise God,
\q2 and I will honor him by thanking him.
\q1

My doing that will please Yahweh more than sacrificing oxen,
\q2 more than offering him full grown bulls.
\q1

Oppressed people will see that God has rescued me,
\q2 and they will be glad.
\q1 I desire that all who request God to help them may be encouraged.
\q1

Yahweh listens to those who are needy;
\q2 he does not ignore those who have suffered for him.
\b
\q1

I desire that everything will praise God—
\q2 everything that is in heaven and on earth and all the creatures that are in the seas.
\q1

God will rescue the people of Jerusalem from their enemies,
\q2 and he will rebuild the towns that are in Judah.
\q1 His people will live there and again possess the land.
\q1

The descendants of his people will inherit it,
\q2 and those who love him will live there safely.

\d A psalm written by David for the choir director, asking God to help David.
\b
\q1

God, please save me!
\q2 Yahweh, come quickly to help me!
\q1

Disgrace those who are happy about my troubles, those who are trying to kill me.
\q2 Chase them away; make everyone shame them, for they want to see me suffer.
\q1

I hope that you will cause them to become dismayed and ashamed
\q2 because they have been happy about my troubles.
\q1

But I hope that everyone who prays to you will rejoice because of you.
\q2 I hope that everyone who waits for you to rescue them will say,
\q1 "God is great!"
\b
\q1

As for me, I am poor and needy;
\q2 so God, come quickly to help me!
\q1 Yahweh, you are the one who saves and helps me,
\q2 so please come quickly!

Be like a huge rock on top of which I can be safe;
\q1 be like a strong fortress in which I am safe.
\q1 You have commanded your angels to rescue me.
\q1

God, rescue me from wicked people,
\q2 from the power of unjust and evil men.
\b
\q1

I have depended on you all my life;
\q2 you have taken care of me since the day that I was born,
\q1 so I will always praise you.
\q1

The manner in which you have rescued me has been an example to many people
\q2 because they realize that you have been my strong defender.
\q1

I praise you all during the day,
\q2 and I proclaim that you are glorious.
\b
\q1

They say, "God has abandoned him;
\q2 so now we can pursue him and seize him
\q2 because there is no one who will rescue him."
\q1

Cause those who accuse me to be defeated and destroyed;
\q2 cause those who want to harm me to be shamed and disgraced.
\b
\q1

But as for me, I will continually and confidently expect you to do great things for me,
\q2 and I will praise you more and more.
\q1

I will tell people that you do what is right;
\q1 all during the day I will tell people how you have saved me,
\q2 although what you have done is more than I can fully understand.
\q1

God, you have taught me many things ever since I was young,
\q2 and I still tell people about your wonderful deeds.
\q1

Now, God, when I am old and my hair is gray,
\q2 do not abandon me.
\q1 Stay with me while I continue to proclaim to my children and grandchildren.
\b
\q1

You have caused us to have many troubles and to suffer much,
\q1 but you will cause us to become strong again;
\q1 when I am almost dead, you will keep us alive.
\q1

You will cause me to be greatly honored,
\q2 and you will encourage me again.
\b
\q1

I will also praise you while I play my harp;
\q1 I will praise you, my God, for faithfully doing what you have promised to do.
\q1 I will play hymns to praise you, the holy God whom we Israelites worship.
\q1

I will shout joyfully while I sing;
\q1 with my entire inner being I will sing
\q2 because you have rescued me.
\q1

All during the day I will tell people that you act righteously
\q2 because those who wanted to harm me will have been defeated and disgraced.

\d A psalm written by Solomon.
\b
\q1

O God, enable the king whom you appointed in Israel to rule justly.
\q2 Show him how to judge matters fairly
\q1

so that he may judge your people fairly
\q2 and that he may govern your oppressed people justly.
\q1

I desire that all over the country—even on the hills and mountains —
\q2 people will live peacefully and righteously.
\q1

Help your king to defend the poor people
\q2 and to rescue needy people and to defeat those who oppress them.
\b
\q1

I desire that your king may live as long as the sun shines,
\q2 as long as the moon shines, forever.
\q1

I desire that his rule may be enjoyed by the people 
\q2 as they enjoy rain on the growing crops,
\q2 as they enjoy the showers that fall on the land.
\q1

I hope that people may live righteously during the years that he rules
\q2 and that the people may live peacefully and prosperously as long as the moon shines.
\b
\q1

I hope that the king of Israel may rule the people
\q2 in all the area from one sea in the east to another in the west
\q2 and from the Euphrates River to the most remote places on earth.
\q1

I hope that those who live in the wilderness may bow down before him
\q2 and that his enemies may throw themselves on the ground in submission to our king.
\q1

I hope that the king of the land of Tarshish and the kings of the islands in the sea may pay taxes to the king of Israel.
\q2 I hope that the king of Sheba to the south and the king of Seba to the southwest may bring him gifts.
\q1

I hope that all the other kings in the world may bow before the king of Israel
\q2 and that people of all nations may serve our king.
\b
\q1

He rescues poor people when they cry out for help,
\q2 and he helps those who are needy and those who have no one to help them.
\q1

Our king rescues people from being oppressed and from being treated cruelly
\q2 because their lives are precious to our king.
\b
\q1

I hope that our king may live a long time!
\q2 I hope that he may be given gold from Sheba.
\q1 I desire that people may always pray for our king
\q2 and praise him all the time, every day.
\q1

I hope that the fields may produce plenty of grain everywhere, even on the tops of the hills in the land where he rules,
\q2 like the grain that grows on the hills in Lebanon.
\q1 I hope that the cities in Israel will be as full of people
\q2 as the fields are full of grass.
\q1

I desire that the name of the king may never be forgotten.
\q2 I hope that people may remember him as long as the sun shines.
\b
\q1 I hope that all people will praise Yahweh, the God of Israel,
\q2 just as he has blessed the king of Israel.
\q1

Praise him forever!
\q2 I desire that his glory may fill the whole world!
\q2 Amen! May it be so!
\b
\q1
This is the end of the prayers written by David, son of Jesse.

God truly is good to us Israelite people,
\q2 to those who, with all their inner being, want to do all that he desires.
\b
\q1

because I saw those who proudly said that they did not need God, and I wanted to be like them.
\q2 I saw that they became wealthy even though they were wicked.
\b
\q1

So they are proud, as proud as a woman with a beautiful necklace.
\q2 They are as proud of their violent actions as some people are proud of their beautiful robes.
\q1

From their inner beings pour out evil deeds,
\q2 and in their inner beings they are always thinking about more evil things to do.
\q1

They say evil things about God, who is in heaven,
\q2 and they talk boastfully about things that they have done here on the earth.
\q1

The result is that people pay attention to them 
\q2 and listen to everything they say.
\q1

Wicked people say to themselves, "God will certainly not know what we have done;
\q2 people say that he is greater than any other god, but he cannot find out."
\b
\q1

That is what wicked people are like;
\q2 they never worry about anything, and they are always becoming richer.
\b
\q1

So, God, I think it is useless that I have always done what you want me to
\q2 and that I have not committed sins.
\q1

During each day I have problems,
\q2 and every morning you punish me.
\b
\q1

But if I had said these things out loud in front of others,
\q2 I would have been sinning against your people.
\q1

When I tried to think completely about these things,
\q2 it was too hard for me to understand them.
\q1

But when I went to your temple, you spoke to me,
\q2 and I understood what will happen to the wicked people after they die.
\b
\q1

Now I know that you will surely put them in dangerous places
\q2 where they will fall down and die.
\q1

They will disappear as quickly as a dream disappears when a person awakes in the morning;
\q2 Lord, when you arise, you will cause them to disappear.
\b
\q1

When I felt sad in my inner being
\q1 and my feelings were hurt,
\q1

I was stupid and ignorant,
\q2 and I behaved like an animal toward you.
\b
\q1

But I am always close to you,
\q1 and you hold my hand.
\q1

You guide me by teaching me,
\q2 and at the end of my life, you will receive me and honor me.
\q1

My body and my mind may become very weak,
\q2 but, God, you continue to enable me to be strong;
\q2 I belong to you forever.
\b
\q1

But as for me, it is wonderful to be near to God
\q2 and to have Yahweh protect me
\q2 and to proclaim to others all that he has done for me.

\d A psalm written by Asaph
\b
\q1

God, why have you abandoned us?
\q2 Will you keep rejecting us forever?
\q1 Why are you angry with us
\q2 since we are like sheep in your pasture and you are like our shepherd? 
\q1

Do not forget your people whom you chose long ago,
\q2 the people whom you freed from being slaves in Egypt and caused to become your tribe.
\q1 Do not forget Jerusalem, which is your home on this earth.
\q1

Walk along and see where everything has been totally ruined;
\q2 our enemies have destroyed everything in the sacred temple.
\b
\q1

They cut down all the engraved objects in the temple as woodsmen cut down trees.
\q1

Then they smashed all the carved wood with their axes and hammers.
\q1

They said to themselves, "We will destroy the Israelites completely,"
\q2 and they also burned down all the other places where we gathered to worship you.
\q1

All our sacred symbols are gone;
\q2 there are no prophets now,
\q2 and no one knows how long this situation will continue.
\b
\q1

God, how long will our enemies make fun of you?
\q1 Will they insult you?
\q1

Why do you refuse to help us?
\q2 Why do you keep your hand inside your cloak instead of using it to destroy our enemies?
\b
\q1

God, you have been our king during all the years since we came out of Egypt,
\q1 and you have enabled us to defeat our enemies in the land of Israel.
\q1

It was as though you crushed the head of the king of Egypt 
\q2 and gave his body to the animals in the desert to eat.
\q1

You caused springs and streams to flow,
\q2 and you also dried up rivers that had never dried up previously.
\q1

You created the days and the nights,
\q2 and you put the sun and the moon in their places.
\q

You determined where the oceans end and the land begins,
\q2 and you created the summer season and the winter season.
\b
\q1

Yahweh, do not forget that your enemies laugh at you
\q1 and that it is foolish people who despise you.
\q1

Do not allow your oppressed people to be disgraced;
\q2 help those poor and needy people in order that they will again praise you.
\b
\q1

God, arise and defend yourself by defending your people!
\q1 Do not forget that foolish people laugh at you all during the day!
\q1

Do not forget that your enemies shout angrily at you;
\q2 the uproar that they make while they oppose you never stops.

\d A psalm written by Asaph for the choir director, to be sung using the tune 'Do not destroy'
\b
\q1

We give thanks to you;
\q2 our God, we thank you.
\q1 You are close to us,
\q2 and we proclaim to others the wonderful things that you have done for us.
\b
\q1

You have said, "I have appointed a time when I will judge people,
\q2 and I will judge everyone fairly.
\q1

When the earth shakes
\q2 and all the creatures on the earth tremble,
\q1 I am the one who will keep its foundations steady.
\q1

I say to people who boast, 'Stop bragging!'
\q1 and I say to wicked people, 'Do not proudly do things to show how great you are!'"
\q

The one who judges people does not come from the east or from the west,
\q1 and he does not come from the desert.
\q1

He promises this: "I will destroy the power of wicked people,
\q1 but I will increase the power of righteous people."

\d A psalm written by Asaph for the choir director, to be accompanied by stringed instruments
\b
\q1

There he broke the flaming arrows that his enemies shot,
\q2 and he also broke their shields and swords and other weapons that they used in battles.
\b
\q1

God, you are powerful! You are like a great king
\q as you return from the mountains where you defeated your enemies.
\q1

Their brave soldiers were killed, and then those who killed them took away everything that those soldiers had.
\q1 Those enemies died;
\q2 indeed, none of them were able to fight any longer.
\q1

When you, the God whom Jacob worshiped, rebuked your enemies,
\q2 their horses and their riders fell down dead.
\q1

Truly, you cause everyone to be afraid.
\q1 When you are angry and you punish people, no one can endure it.
\q1

From heaven you proclaimed that you would judge people,
\q2 and then everyone on the earth was afraid and did not say anything more
\q2

when you arose to declare that you would punish wicked people
\q2 and rescue all those whom they had oppressed.
\b
\q1

When you punish those with whom you are angry, your people will praise you,
\q2 and your enemies who survive will worship you on your festival days.
\b
\q1

He humbles the leaders,
\q2 and terrifies all the kings.

\d A psalm written by Asaph for Jeduthun, the choir director
\b
\q1

At the time that I had trouble, I prayed to the Lord;
\q2 all during the night I lifted up my hands while I prayed,
\q2 but nothing could comfort me.
\b
\q1

"Will the Lord always reject me?
\q2 Will he never again be pleased with me?
\q1

Has he stopped faithfully loving me?
\q1 Will he not do for me what he promised to do?
\q1

God promised to act mercifully toward me; has he forgotten that?
\q2 Because he is angry with me, has he decided not to be kind to me?"
\q1

I said, "What causes me to be sad the most is that
\q1 it seems that God, who is greater than any other god, is no longer using his power for us."
\b
\q1

I meditate on all that you have done,
\q2 and I think about your mighty acts.
\b
\q1

By your power you rescued your people from Egypt;
\q2 you saved those who were descendants of Jacob and his son Joseph.
\b
\q1

It was as though the waters saw you and became very afraid,
\q2 and even the deepest part of the water shook.
\q

Rain poured down from the clouds;
\q2 it thundered very loudly,
\q2 and lightning flashed in all directions.
\q

Thunder crashed in the whirlwind—your voice!
\q2 Lightning lit up,
\q1 and the earth shook violently.
\q1

Then you walked through the sea
\q2 in a path that you made through the deep water,
\q2 but your footprints could not be seen.
\b
\q1

You led your people as a shepherd leads his flock of sheep
\q2 while Moses and Aaron were the leaders of your people.

I am going to give you some sayings that wise people have said.
\q2 They will be sayings about things that happened long ago,
\q2 things that were difficult to understand.
\q1

These are things that we have heard and known previously,
\q2 things that our parents and grandparents told us.
\q1

We will tell these things to our children,
\q1 but we will also tell our grandchildren
\q2 about Yahweh's power and the glorious things that he has done.
\q1

He gave laws and commandments to the Israelite people,
\q1 those who are the descendants of Jacob,
\q1 and he told our ancestors to teach them to their children.
\q1

He commanded this so that their children would also know them
\q2 and so that they would teach them to their own children.
\q1

In that way, they also would trust in God
\q2 and would not forget the things that he has done;
\q1 instead, they would obey his commandments.
\q1

They would not be like their ancestors,
\q2 who were very stubborn and kept rebelling against God;
\q1 they did not continue firmly trusting in God,
\q2 and they did not worship him alone.
\b
\q1

The soldiers of the tribe of Ephraim had bows and arrows,
\q1 but they ran away from their enemies on the day that they fought with their enemies.
\q1

While our ancestors were watching,
\q1 God performed miracles in the area around the city of Zoan in Egypt.
\q1

Then he caused the Sea of Reeds to divide,
\q2 causing the water on each side to pile up like a wall,
\q2 with the result that our ancestors walked through it on dry ground.
\q1

He led them by a bright cloud during the day
\q1 and by a fiery light during the night.
\q1

He split rocks open in the wilderness
\q1 and gave to our ancestors plenty of water from deep inside the earth.
\q1

He caused a stream of water to flow from the rock;
\q2 the water flowed like a river.
\b
\q1

By demanding that God give them the food that they desired,
\q1 they tried to find out if he would always do what they requested him to do.
\q1

They insulted God by saying, "Can God supply food for us here in this desert?
\q1

It is true that he struck the rock,
\q2 with the result that water gushed out,
\q1 but can he also provide bread and meat for us, his people?"
\q1

So when Yahweh heard that, he became very angry,
\q2 and he sent a fire to burn up some of his Israelite people. 
\q2

He did that because they did not trust in him,
\q2 and they did not believe that he would rescue them.
\q1

But God spoke to the sky above them
\q2 and commanded it to open like a door,
\q1

and then food fell down like rain,
\q3 food that they named "manna."
\q2 God gave them grain from heaven.
\q1

So the people ate the food that angels eat,
\q2 and God gave to them all the manna that they wanted.
\q1

Later, he caused the wind to blow from the east,
\q2 and by his power he also sent wind from the south,
\q1

and the wind brought birds
\q2 which were as numerous as the grains of sand on the seashore.
\q1

God caused those birds to fall in the middle of their camp.
\q2 There were birds all around their tents.
\q1

So the people cooked the birds and ate the meat; their stomachs were full
\q2 because God had given them what they wanted.
\q1

But they had not yet eaten all that they wanted.
\q1

At that point, God was still very angry with them,
\q2 and he caused their strongest men to die;
\q2 he got rid of many of the finest young Israelite men.
\b
\q1

In spite of all this, the people continued to sin;
\q1 in spite of all the miracles that God had performed,
\q2 they still did not trust that he would take care of them.
\q1

Whenever God caused some of the Israelites to die,
\q1 the others would repent;
\q1 they would be sorry and seriously ask God to save them.
\q1

They would remember that God was like a huge rock on which they would be safe,
\q1 and that he, who was greater than any other god, was the one who protected them.
\q1

But God acted mercifully toward his people.
\q1 He forgave them for having sinned
\q2 and did not get rid of them.
\q1 Many times he refrained from becoming angry with them
\q1 and restrained himself from furiously punishing them.
\q1

He remembered that they were only humans who die,
\q2 humans who disappear as quickly as a wind that blows by and then is gone.
\b
\q1

Many times our ancestors rebelled against God in the wilderness
\q1 and made him very sad.
\q1

Many times they did evil things to find out if they could do those things without God punishing them.
\q2 They frequently caused the holy God of Israel to become angry.
\q1

They forgot about his great power,
\q2 and they forgot about the time when he rescued them from their enemies.
\q1

They forgot about when he performed many miracles
\q2 in the area near the city of Zoan in Egypt.
\q1

He caused the Nile River to become red like blood
\q2 so that the people of Egypt had no water to drink.
\q1

He sent among the people of Egypt swarms of flies that bit them,
\q1 and he sent frogs that ate up everything.
\q1

He sent locusts to eat their crops
\q1 and the other things that grew in their fields.
\q1

He sent hail that destroyed the grapevines,
\q1 and he sent more hail that ruined the figs on the sycamore trees.
\q1

He sent hail that killed their cattle
\q1 and lightning that killed their sheep and cows.
\q1

Because God was fiercely angry with the people of Egypt,
\q1 he caused them to be very distressed.
\q2 The disasters that struck them were like a group of angels that destroyed everything.
\q1

He did not lessen his anger with them,
\q2 and he did not spare their lives;
\q1 he sent a plague that killed many of them.
\q1

In that plague he caused all the firstborn sons of the people of Egypt to die.
\q1

Then he led his people out of Egypt as a shepherd leads his sheep,
\q2 and he guided them while they walked through the wilderness.
\q1

He led them safely, and they were not afraid,
\q1 but their enemies were drowned in the sea.
\q1

Later he brought them to Canaan, his sacred land,
\q2 to Mount Zion,
\q2 and by his power he enabled them to conquer the people who were living there.
\q1

He expelled the people groups while his people were advancing;
\q2 he assigned part of the land for each tribe to possess,
\q2 and he gave the houses of those people to the Israelites.
\b
\q1

However, the Israelites rebelled against God, who is greater than any other God,
\q2 and they did many evil things to see if they could do those things without God punishing them;
\q2 they did not obey his commandments.
\q1

Because they worshiped carved images of their gods on the tops of hills,
\q1 they caused God to become angry.
\q1

He saw what they were doing and became very angry,
\q2 so he rejected the Israelite people.
\q1

He no longer appeared to them at Shiloh
\q2 in the sacred tent where he had lived among them.
\q1

He allowed their enemies to capture the sacred chest,
\q2 which was the symbol of his power and his glory.
\q1

Because he was angry with his people,
\q2 he allowed their enemies to kill them.
\q1

Young men were killed in battles,
\q2 with the result that the young women had no one to marry.
\q1

Many priests were killed by their enemies' swords,
\q2 and the people did not allow the priests' widows to mourn.
\b
\q1

He pushed his enemies back
\q1 and caused them to be very ashamed for a long time 
\q2 because they had been defeated.
\q1

He decided to have his temple built there, high up, like his home in heaven;
\q1 he caused it to be firm, like the earth,
\q2 and intended that his temple would last forever.
\q1

where he was taking care of his father's sheep,
\q1 and appointed him to be the leader of the Israelites,
\q2 the people who would always belong to God.
\q1

David took care of the Israelite people sincerely and wholeheartedly,
\q2 and he guided them skillfully.

\d A psalm written by Asaph
\b
\q1

God, other people groups have invaded your own land.
\q2 They have desecrated your temple,
\q1 and they have destroyed all the buildings in Jerusalem.
\q1

Instead of burying the corpses of your people whom they killed,
\q2 they allowed the vultures to eat the flesh of those corpses,
\q2 and they also allowed wild animals to eat the corpses of your people.
\q1

When they killed your people,
\q1 your people's blood flowed like water through the streets of Jerusalem,
\q2 and there was almost no one left to bury their corpses.
\q1

The people groups that live in countries that surround our land insult us;
\q2 they laugh at us and mock us.
\b
\q1

Yahweh, how long will this continue?
\q2 Will you be angry with us forever?
\q1 Will your anger be like a fire burning within you?
\q1

Instead of being angry with us,
\q2 be angry with the people groups that do not know you!
\q1 Be angry with kingdoms whose people do not pray to you
\q2

because they have killed Israelite people
\q2 and they have ruined your country.
\q1

Do not punish us because of the sins that our ancestors committed!
\q1 Act mercifully toward us now
\q2 because we are very discouraged.
\b
\q1

God, you have saved us many times,
\q2 so help us now;
\q1 rescue us and forgive us for having sinned
\q2 so that other people will honor you.
\q1

It is not right that the other people groups say about us,
\q2 "If their God is very powerful, why does he not help them?"
\q1 Allow us to see you punishing the people of other nations in return for their shedding our blood
\q1 and killing many of us, your people.
\q1

Listen to your people groaning while they are in prison,
\q2 and by your great power, free those whom our enemies say they will certainly execute.
\b
\q1

In return for their having often insulted you,
\q1 punish them seven times as much!
\q1

After you do that, we, whom you take care of as a shepherd takes care of his sheep, will continue praising you;
\q2 we will continue to praise you from generation to generation forever.

\d A psalm written by Asaph for the choir director, to be sung using the tune 'Lilies of the covenant'
\b
\q1

Yahweh, you who lead us as a shepherd leads his flock of sheep,
\q1 you who sit on your throne in the Very Holy Place in the temple, above the figures of winged creatures,
\q1 come and do powerful things for us Israelite people.
\q1

Show yourself to the people of the tribes of Ephraim and Benjamin and Manasseh!
\q2 Show us that you are powerful
\q2 and come and rescue us!
\b
\q1

God, cause our nation to be strong like it was before;
\q2 act kindly toward us so that we may be saved from our enemies!
\b
\q1

Yahweh, commander of the angel armies,
\q2 how long will you be angry with us, your people, when we pray to you?
\q1

It is as though the only food and drink that you have given us is a cup full of our tears!
\q1

You have allowed the people groups that surround us to argue with each other to decide which part of our land each of them will take;
\q2 they laugh at us.
\b
\q1

God, Commander of the angel armies,
\q2 make our nation strong as it was before!
\q1 Act kindly toward us so that we may be saved!
\b
\q1

Our ancestors were like a grapevine that you brought out of Egypt;
\q1 you drove out the other people groups from this land,
\q2 and you put your people in their land.
\q1

As people clear ground to plant a grapevine,
\q1 you cleared out the people who were living in this land for us to live in it.
\q1 As the roots of a grapevine go deep down into the ground and spread,
\q2 you enabled our ancestors to prosper and start living in towns all over this land.
\q1

As huge grapevines cover the hills with their shade
\q2 and as their branches are taller than big cedar trees,
\q1

your people ruled all of Canaan, from the Mediterranean Sea in the west to the Euphrates River in the east.
\b
\q1

So why have you abandoned us
\q2 and allowed our enemies to tear down our walls?
\q1 You are like someone who tears down the fences around his vineyard,
\q2 so that all the people who pass by can steal the grapes;
\q2

wild pigs can trample the vines,
\q2 and wild animals can also eat the grapes.
\q1

You who are the commander of the angel armies, turn to us!
\q2 Look down from heaven and see what is happening to us!
\q1 Come and rescue us who are like your grapevine,
\q1

who are like the young vine that you planted and caused to grow!
\b
\q1

But strengthen us people whom you have chosen,
\q2 us Israelite people, whom you previously caused to be very strong.
\q

When you do that, we will never turn away from you again;
\q2 revive us, and then we will praise you.
\b
\q1

Yahweh, commander of the angel armies, restore us;
\q2 act kindly toward us and rescue us from our enemies!

\d A psalm written by Asaph for the choir director
\b
\q1

Start playing the music, and beat the tambourines;
\q2 play nice music on the harps and lyres.
\b
\q1

Blow the trumpets during the festival to celebrate each new moon,
\q2 each time the moon is full, and during our other festivals.
\q1

He gave it to the Israelite people when he punished the people of Egypt land.
\b
\q1 That was where I heard them speaking in a language that I did not know.
\q1

God says this: "After the rulers of Egypt forced you Israelites to work as slaves,
\q1 I took those heavy burdens off your backs,
\q2 and I enabled you to lay down those heavy baskets of bricks that you were carrying.
\q1

When you were greatly distressed, you called out to me, and I rescued you;
\q2 I answered you out of a thundercloud.
\q2 Later I tested whether you would trust me to give you water when you were in the desert at Meribah.
\q1

You who are my people, listen while I warn you!
\q1 I wish that you Israelite people would pay attention to what I say to you!
\q1

So because they were very stubborn,
\q2 I allowed them to do whatever they wanted to do.
\b
\q1

I wish that my people would listen to me,
\q1 that the Israelite people would behave as I want them to do.
\q1

Then all those who hate me would cringe before me,
\q2 and then I would punish them forever.
\q1

But I would give you Israelites very good wheat,
\q2 and I would fill your stomachs with wild honey."

God stands in heaven in a meeting of all the spirits whom he has placed in charge of what he created.
\q2 He tells them that he has decided this:
\q1

Rescue them from the power of the wicked people!"
\b
\q1

Those rulers do not know or understand anything!
\q2 They are very corrupt,
\q2 and as a result of their corrupt behavior,
\q2 it is as though the foundation of the world is being shaken!
\b
\q1

I previously said to them, "You think you are gods!
\q1 It is as though you are all my sons,
\q1

but you will die as people do;
\q2 your lives will end as the lives of all rulers end."
\b
\q1

God, arise and judge everyone on the earth
\q2 because all the people groups belong to you!

\d A psalm which is a song written by Asaph
\b
\q1

God, do not continue to be silent!
\q1 Do not be quiet and say nothing
\q1

They say, "Come, we must destroy their nation
\q2 so that no one will remember that Israel ever existed!"
\q1

They have agreed on what they want to do to destroy Israel,
\q2 and they have agreed to attack you together—
\q1

the people who live in the tents of Edom— 
\q2 the Ishmaelites, Moab and the Hagrites, they conspire together with

the people of Gebal, and the Ammonites, and the Amalekites,
\q2 and the Philistines, and the people of the city of Tyre.
\q2

The people of Assyria have joined them;
\q2 they are strong allies of the Moab and Ammon people groups, who are descendants of Abraham's nephew Lot.
\b
\q1

God, do to those people things as you did to the Midian people group,
\q2 as you did to Sisera and Jabin at the Kishon River.
\q1

You destroyed them at the town of Endor,
\q2 and their corpses lay on the ground and decayed.
\q1

who said, "We will take for ourselves the land that the Israelites say belongs to God!"
\b
\q1

My God, cause them to disappear quickly like whirling dust,
\q2 like chaff that the wind blows away!
\q1

As a fire completely burns a forest
\q1 and as flames burn in the mountains,
\q1

expel them with your storms
\q2 and cause them to be terrified by your big storms!
\q1

Cause them to be very ashamed
\q2 so that they will admit that you are very powerful.
\q1

Cause them to be forever disgraced because of being defeated,
\q1 and cause them to die while they are still disgraced.
\q1

Cause them to know that you, whose name is Yahweh,
\q2 are the supreme ruler over everything on the earth.

\d A psalm written by one of the descendants of Korah for the choir director
\b
\q1

Yahweh, commander of the angel armies,
\q2 your temple is very beautiful!
\q1

I would like to be there;
\q2 Yahweh, I desire that very much.
\q2 With all my inner being I sing joyfully to you, the all-powerful God.
\b
\q1

Even sparrows and swallows have built nests near your temple;
\q2 they take care of their young babies near the altars where people offer sacrifices to you,
\q2 Commander of the angel armies, my king and my God.
\q1

How fortunate are those who are always in your temple,
\q2 constantly singing to praise you.
\b
\q1

How fortunate are those whom you make strong,
\q1 those who desire very much to make the trip up to Mount Zion.
\q1

While they travel through the dry Valley of Tears,
\q1 you cause it to become a place where there are springs of water,
\q2 where the rains in the autumn fill the valley with water, a blessing from you.
\q1

As a result, those who travel through there become stronger
\q2 knowing that they will appear in your presence on Mount Zion.
\b
\q1

God, act kindly toward our king, the one who protects us,
\q2 the one whom you have chosen to rule us.
\b
\q1

For me, spending one day in your temple
\q2 is better than spending a thousand days somewhere else;
\q1 standing at the entrance to your temple, ready to go inside,
\q2 is better than living in the tents where wicked people live.
\q1

Yahweh our God is like the sun that shines on us and like a shield that protects us;
\q2 he acts favorably toward us and honors us.
\q1 Yahweh does not refuse to give any good thing to those who do what is right.
\b
\q1

Yahweh, commander of the angel armies,
\q2 how fortunate are those who trust in you!

\d A psalm written by one of the descendants of Korah for the choir director
\b
\q1

You stopped being angry with us
\q2 and turned away from severely punishing us.
\b
\q1

Now, God, the only one who can save us, stop being angry with us 
\q1 and help us.
\q1

Please enable us to prosper again
\q2 so that we, your people, will rejoice about what you have done for us.
\q1

Yahweh, by rescuing us from our troubles,
\q2 show us that you faithfully love us.
\b
\q1

I want to listen to what Yahweh our God says
\q2 because he promises that he will enable us, his people, to live peacefully
\q2 if we do not return to doing foolish things.
\q1

He is surely ready to save those who have an awesome respect for him,
\q2 so that his glory will remain in our land.
\b
\q1

When that happens, he will both faithfully love us and faithfully do for us what he promised to do;
\q1 we will act righteously, and he will give us peace,
\q2 which will be like a kiss that he gives us.
\q1

Here on earth, we will be loyal to God,
\q1 and from heaven, God will act justly toward us.
\q1

Yes, Yahweh will do good things for us,
\q2 and there will be great harvests in our land.
\q1

Yahweh always acts righteously;
\q2 he acts righteously wherever he goes.

\d A prayer written by David
\b
\q1

Yahweh, listen to what I say and answer me
\q2 because I am weak and needy.
\q1

Lord, act kindly toward me
\q2 because I cry out to you all during each day.
\q1

Lord, cause me to be glad,
\q2 because I pray to you.
\b
\q1

When I have troubles, I call out to you
\q2 because you answer me.
\b
\q1

Lord, among all the gods whom the heathen nations worship,
\q2 there is no one like you;
\q1 not one of them has done the great things that you have done.
\q1
